From Recusrion to Iteration

  • Unwind the recursion and convert it into iteration
  • Can compute values of MMM iteratively in O(n)O(n)O(n) time
  • Find solution works as before

Basic Outline of Dynamic Programming

  • need a collection of sub-problems that satisfy a few properties
  • There are a polynomial number of sub problems
  • The solution to the problem can by computed easily from the solutions to the sub problems
  • There is a natural ordering from "smallest" to "largest"
  • There is an easy to compute recurrence that allows us to compute the solution to the sub-problems from solutions to some smaller sub problems

Least Squares Problem

  • Given a set of scientific or statistical data plotted on two axes, find the best line that passes through these points
  • Instance: Set P={(x1,y1),(x2,y2),...,(xn,yn)}P = \{(x_1, y_1), (x_2, y_2), ... , (x_n, y_n)\}P={(x1​,y1​),(x2​,y2​),...,(xn​,yn​)} of nnn points
  • Solution: Line L:y=ax+bL: y = ax + bL:y=ax+b that minimizes Error(L,P) =∑i=1n(yi−axi−b)2= \displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^n(y_i - ax_i - b)^2=i=1∑n​(yi​−axi​−b)2

  • How many unknown paramters must we find values for?

    • a,ba,ba,b via lagrangian
    • a=n∑xiyi−(∑xi)(∑yi)n∑xi2−(∑xi)2a = \frac{n\sum x_i y_i - (\sum x_i)(\sum y_i)}{n \sum x_i^2 - (\sum x_i)^2}a=n∑xi2​−(∑xi​)2n∑xi​yi​−(∑xi​)(∑yi​)​ and b=∑yi−a∑xinb = \frac{\sum y_i - a \sum x_i}{n}b=n∑yi​−a∑xi​​

Segmented Least Squares

  • Want to fit multiple lines through PPP
  • Each line must fit contiguus set of x-coordinates
  • Lines must minimize total error
  • Divide the points into segments; each segment contains a consecutive set of points ordered by increasing x-coordinate
  • Instance: Set P={pi=(xi,yi),1≤i≤n}P = \{p_i = (x_i, y_i), 1 \leq i \leq n\}P={pi​=(xi​,yi​),1≤i≤n} of nnn points, x1<x2<...<xnx_1 < x_2 < ... < x_nx1​<x2​<...<xn​ and a parameter C>0C > 0C>0

  • Solution

    • an integer kkk
    • a partition of PPP into kkk segments {P1,P2,...,Pk}\{P_1, P_2, ..., P_k\}{P1​,P2​,...,Pk​}
    • for each segment PjP_jPj​, the best fit line Lj:y=ajx+bj,1≤j≤kL_j: y = a_jx + b_j, 1 \leq j \leq kLj​:y=aj​x+bj​,1≤j≤k that minimises the total error ∑j=1kError(Lj,Pj)+Ck\displaystyle\sum_{j=1}^k Error(L_j, P_j) + Ckj=1∑k​Error(Lj​,Pj​)+Ck
  • if CCC is very large then one line works, if CCC is small, then we fit many lines
  • How many unknown parameters here? 2k,k2k, k2k,k since we need to find the slope and intercept of kkk lines as well a the optimal value of kkk itself

Formulating the Recursion

  • Let eje_jej​ deonte the minmium error of a (single) line that fits {p1,p2,...,pi}\{p_1, p_2, ..., p_i\}{p1​,p2​,...,pi​}
  • Let OPT(i)OPT(i)OPT(i) be the optimal total error for the points {p1,p2,...,pi}\{p_1, p_2, ..., p_i\}{p1​,p2​,...,pi​}
  • We want to compute OPT(n)OPT(n)OPT(n)
  • Observation: Where does the last segment in the optimal solution end? pnp_npn​, and this segment starts at some point pip_ipi​. So the rest of the solution must be the optimal fit for points up to pip_ipi​: OPT(i−1)OPT(i-1)OPT(i−1)
  • OPT(n)OPT(n)OPT(n) is the error for the line that goes through points i,ni, ni,n plus the penalty for adding a line CCC plus the best solution for the last i−1i-1i−1 points

  • If the last segment in the optimal solution is {pi,pi+1,...,pn}\{p_i, p_{i+1}, ..., p_n\}{pi​,pi+1​,...,pn​}, then

    OPT(n)=ei,n+C+OPT(i−1)OPT(n) = e_i,n + C + OPT(i-1)OPT(n)=ei​,n+C+OPT(i−1)

  • Suppose we want to solve the sub-problem on the first jjj points: {p1,p2,...,pj}\{p_1, p_2, ..., p_j\}{p1​,p2​,...,pj​}: we want to compute OPT(j)OPT(j)OPT(j)

  • If the last sigment in the optimal partition is {pi,pi+1,...,pj}\{p_i, p_{i+1}, ..., p_j\}{pi​,pi+1​,...,pj​} then

    OPT(j)=ei,j+C+OPT(i−1)OPT(j) = e_i,j + C + OPT(i-1)OPT(j)=ei​,j+C+OPT(i−1)

  • But iii can take only jjj distinct values: 1,2,3,...,j1, 2, 3, ..., j1,2,3,...,j therefore:

    OPT(j)=min⁡1≤i≤j(ei,j+C+OPT(i−1))OPT(j) = \min \limits_{1 \leq i \leq j} (e_i,j + C + OPT(i-1))OPT(j)=1≤i≤jmin​(ei​,j+C+OPT(i−1))

  • Segment {pi,pi+1,...,pj}ispartoftheoptimalsolutionforthissub−problemiffthevaluesof\{p_i, p_{i+1}, ..., p_j\} is part of the optimal solution for this sub-problem iff the values of{pi​,pi+1​,...,pj​}ispartoftheoptimalsolutionforthissub−problemiffthevaluesofOPT(j) is obtained using index iii

DP Algorithm

Segmented-Least-Squares(n)Array M[0,...,n]Set M[0]=0For all pairs i≤jCompute the least squares error ei,j for the segment pi,...,pjForj=1,2,...,nUse the recurrence from (6.7) to compute M[j]Return M[n]\boxed{ \begin{aligned} &\texttt{Segmented-Least-Squares}(n) \\ &\text{Array } M[0, ..., n] \\ &\text{Set } M[0] = 0 \\ &\text{For all pairs } i \leq j \\ &\quad\text{Compute the least squares error } e_{i,j} \text{ for the segment } p_i, ..., p_j\\ &\text{For} j = 1,2, ..., n \\ &\quad\text{Use the recurrence from (6.7) to compute } M[j] \\ &\text{Return } M[n] \end{aligned} } ​Segmented-Least-Squares(n)Array M[0,...,n]Set M[0]=0For all pairs i≤jCompute the least squares error ei,j​ for the segment pi​,...,pj​Forj=1,2,...,nUse the recurrence from (6.7) to compute M[j]Return M[n]​​
  • Computing OPT(j)OPT(j)OPT(j) takes O(j)O(j)O(j)
  • ∑j=1nO(j)=O(n2)\sum_{j=1}^n O(j) = O(n^2)∑j=1n​O(j)=O(n2)
∑1≤i≤jO(j−i)=j(j−1)/2≤∑j2/2≤∑j2\begin{aligned} \displaystyle\sum_{1 \leq i \leq j} O(j - i) &= j(j-1)/2 \\ &\leq \sum j^2/2 \\ &\leq \sum j^2 \end{aligned}1≤i≤j∑​O(j−i)​=j(j−1)/2≤∑j2/2≤∑j2​

  • Let T(n)T(n)T(n) be the running time of this algorithm (j−ij - ij−i since we compute segments)

    T(n)=∑i≤j≤n∑1≤i≤jO(j−i)=O(n3)T(n) = \displaystyle\sum_{i \leq j \leq n}\sum_{1 \leq i \leq j} O(j - i) = O(n^3)T(n)=i≤j≤n∑​1≤i≤j∑​O(j−i)=O(n3)

RNA Molecules

  • basic biolegical molecule. Single stranded
  • RNA molecules fold into complex "secondary structures"
  • Secondary structure governs the behavior of an RNA molecule
  • carious rules govern secondary structure formation
  • Pairs of bases match up; each base matches with ≤ 1 other base
  • Adenine : Uracil
  • Cytosine : Guanine
  • There are no kinks in the folded molecule
  • Structures are "knot-free"
  • High level problem: given an RNA molecule, predict its secondary structure

Formulating the Problem

  • an RNA Molecule is a string B=b1b2...bnB = b_1 b_2 ... b_nB=b1​b2​...bn​; each bi∈{A,C,G,U}b_i \in \{A, C, G, U\}bi​∈{A,C,G,U}

  • A secondary structure on BBB is a set of pairs S={(i,j)}S = \{(i,j)\}S={(i,j)} where 1≤i,j≤n1 \leq i,j \leq n1≤i,j≤n and

    • No kinks: if (i,j)∈S(i,j) \in S(i,j)∈S then i<j−4i < j - 4i<j−4
    • Watson Crick: The elements in each pair of SSS consist of either {A,U}\{A, U\}{A,U} or {c,G}\{c, G\}{c,G}
    • SSS is a matching: no index appears in more than one pair
    • No knots: If (i,j)(i, j)(i,j) and (k,l)(k, l)(k,l) are two pairs in SSS, then we cannot have i<k<j<li < k < j < li<k<j<l
  • The Energy of a secondary structure ∝\propto∝ the number of base pairs in it.
  • Problem: Compute the largest secondary structure, i.e. with the largest number of base pairs

Dynamic Programming Approach

  • OPT(j)OPT(j)OPT(j) is the maximum number of base pairs in a secondary structure for b1b2...bjb_1b_2...b_jb1​b2​...bj​, OP(j)=0,j≤5OP(j) = 0, j \leq 5OP(j)=0,j≤5

  • In the optimal secondary structure on b1b2...bjb_1b_2...b_jb1​b2​...bj​

    • If jjj is not a member of any pair, use OPT(j−1)OPT(j-1)OPT(j−1)

    • If jjj pairs with some t<j−4t < j - 4t<j−4, then the knot condition yields tow independent sub-problems: OPT(t−1)OPT(t-1)OPT(t−1), ???

      • Note that we need that sub-problems to be indexed by both start and by end
  • OPT(i,j)OPT(i,j)OPT(i,j) is the maximum number of base pairs in a secondary structure for bibi+1...bjb_ib_{i+1}...b_jbi​bi+1​...bj​, OPT(i,j)=0,i≥j−4OPT(i,j) = 0, i \geq j-4OPT(i,j)=0,i≥j−4

  • In the optimal secondary structure on bibi+2...bjb_ib_{i+2}...b_jbi​bi+2​...bj​

    • If jjj is not a member of any pair, compute OPT(i,j−1)OPT(i, j-1)OPT(i,j−1)
    • If jjj pairs with somme t<j−4t < j -4t<j−4, compute OPT(i,t−1)OPT(i, t-1)OPT(i,t−1) and OPT(t+1,j−1)OPT(t+1, j-1)OPT(t+1,j−1)

OPT(i,j)=max⁡(OPT(i,j−1),max⁡t(1+OPT(i,t−1)+OPT(t+1,j−1)))OPT(i,j) = \max \Big( OPT(i, j-1), \max \limits_t (1 + OPT(i, t-1) + OPT(t+1, j-1)) \Big)OPT(i,j)=max(OPT(i,j−1),tmax​(1+OPT(i,t−1)+OPT(t+1,j−1)))

  • In the "inner" maximisation, ttt runs over all indices between i,j−5i,j-5i,j−5 that are allowed to pair with jjj
  • There are O(n2)O(n^2)O(n2) sub-problems: we have a matrix of i,ji,ji,j with the lower right triangle filled out: ∑j=5n∑i=1j=n3\sum_{j=5}^n \sum_{i=1}^j = n^3∑j=5n​∑i=1j​=n3 since the inner summation is less than j(j−1)/2j(j-1)/2j(j−1)/2 which we then sum another nnn times
  • How do we order them from "smallest" to "largest"? increasing order of j−ij-ij−i
  • Note that computing OPT(i,j)OPT(i,j)OPT(i,j)? O(i−j)O(i-j)O(i−j) : involves sub-problems OPT(l,m)OPT(l,m)OPT(l,m) where m−l<j−im - l < j - im−l<j−i
Initialize OPT(i,j) = 0 whenever i≥j−4For k=5,6,...,n−1For i=1,2,...,n−kSet j=i+kCompute OPT(i,j) using the recurrence above Return OPT(1,n)\boxed{ \begin{aligned} &\text{Initialize OPT(i,j) = 0 whenever } i \geq j -4\\ &\text{For } k = 5,6,...,n-1 \\ &\quad\text{For } i = 1,2,...,n-k \\ &\qquad\text{Set } j = i + k \\ &\qquad\text{Compute } OPT(i,j) \text{ using the recurrence above }\\ &\text{Return } OPT(1,n) \end{aligned} } ​Initialize OPT(i,j) = 0 whenever i≥j−4For k=5,6,...,n−1For i=1,2,...,n−kSet j=i+kCompute OPT(i,j) using the recurrence above Return OPT(1,n)​​
  • Total running time for the algorithm is O(n3)O(n^3)O(n3)

Dynamic Programming for Shortest Path

Motivation

  • Computational finance

    • Each node is a financial agent
    • The cost cuvc_{uv}cuv​ of an edge (u,v)(u,v)(u,v) is the cost of a transaction in which we buy from agent uuu and sell to agent vvv
    • Negative cost corresponds to profit

  • Internet routing protocols

    • Dijkstra's algorithm needs knowledge of the entire network
    • Routers only know which other routers they are connected to
    • Algorithm for shortest paths with negative edges is decentralized
    • Not covered in class, but described in Chapter 6.9

Problem Statement

  • Input: a directed graph G=(V,E)G = (V,E)G=(V,E) with a cost function c:E→Rc: E \rightarrow \realsc:E→R i.e., cuvc_{uv}cuv​ is the cost of the edge (u,v)∈E(u,v) \in E(u,v)∈E
  • A negative cycle is a directed graph whose edges have a total cost that is negative

  • Two related problems:

    • If GGG has no negative cycles, find the shortest s-t path: a path from source sss to destination ttt with minimum total cost
    • Does GGG have a negative cycle?

Approaches for Shortest Path Algorithm

  1. Dijkstra's
  2. Computes incorrect answers because it is greedy
  3. Add some largest constant to each edge
  4. Computes incorrect answers because the minimum cost path changes

DP Approach

  • Assume GGG has no negative cycles
  • Claim: there is a shortest path from sss to ttt that is simple (does not repeat a node) and therefore has at most n−1n-1n−1 edges

  • How do we define sub-problems?

    • Proof: The portion of the s→ts \rightarrow ts→t path between the two appearances of the node uuu must have a positive cost
    • Shortest s→ts \rightarrow ts→t path has ≤n−1\leq n -1≤n−1 edges: how can we reach ttt using iii edges, for different values of iii?
    • We do not know which nodes will be in shortest s→ts \rightarrow ts→t path: how we can reach ttt from each node in VVV
  • Sub-problems defined by varying the number of edges in the shortest path and by varying the starting node in the shortest path

DP Recursion

  • OPT(i,v)OPT(i,v)OPT(i,v): minimum cost of a v→tv \rightarrow tv→t path that uses at most iii edges
  • ttt is not explicitly mentioned in the sub-problems
  • Goal is to compute OPT(n−1,s)OPT(n - 1, s)OPT(n−1,s)

  • Let PPP be the optimal path whose cost is OPT(i,v)OPT(i,v)OPT(i,v)

    • If PPP actually uses i−1i -1i−1 edges, then OPT(i,v)=OPT(i−v)OPT(i,v) = OPT(i - v)OPT(i,v)=OPT(i−v)
    • If first node on PPP is www, then OPT(i,v)=cvw+OPT(i−1,wOPT(i,v) = c_{vw} + OPT(i -1, wOPT(i,v)=cvw​+OPT(i−1,w
OPT(0,v)={0;v=t∞;v≠t OPT(0, v) = \begin{cases} 0; v = t \\ \infty; v \neq t \end{cases}OPT(0,v)={0;v=t∞;v​=t​

OPT(i,v)=min⁡(OPT(i−v),min⁡w∈V(cvw+OPT(i−1,w)))OPT(i,v) = \min \Big(OPT(i-v), \min \limits_{w \in V} (c_{vw} + OPT(i -1, w)) \Big)OPT(i,v)=min(OPT(i−v),w∈Vmin​(cvw​+OPT(i−1,w)))

Alternate DP Forumlation

  • OPT(i,v)OPT(i,v)OPT(i,v): minimum cost of a v→tv \rightarrow tv→t path that uses exactly iii edges
  • a bit harder, but it's in the slides

Bellman-Ford Algorithm

Shortest-Path(G,s,t)n=∣V∣∈Gm[0,...,n−1,V]DefineM[0,t]=0,M[0,v]=∞ for all other v∈VFor i=1,2,...,n−1For eachv∈V (in any order)ComputeM[i,v] using the recurrenceReturn M[n−1,s]\boxed{ \begin{aligned} &\texttt{Shortest-Path}(G,s,t)\\ &n = |V| \in G \\ &m[0, ... , n-1, V] \\ &\text{Define} M[0,t]=0, M[0,v] = \infty \text{ for all other } v \in V \\ &\text{For } i = 1,2, ..., n -1 \\ &\quad\text{For each} v \in V \text{ (in any order)} \\ &\qquad\text{Compute} M[i,v] \text{ using the recurrence} \\ &\text{Return } M[n - 1, s] \end{aligned} } ​Shortest-Path(G,s,t)n=∣V∣∈Gm[0,...,n−1,V]DefineM[0,t]=0,M[0,v]=∞ for all other v∈VFor i=1,2,...,n−1For eachv∈V (in any order)ComputeM[i,v] using the recurrenceReturn M[n−1,s]​​
  • space used is O(n2)O(n^2)O(n2), running time is O(n3)O(n^3)O(n3)
  • If shortest path uses kkk edges, we can recover it in O(kn)O(kn)O(kn) time by tracing back through smaller sub-problems

An Improved Bound on the Running Time

  • Suppose GGG has nnn nodes and m≪(n2)m \ll {n \choose 2}m≪(2n​) edges. Can we demonstrate a better upper bound on the running time

M[i,v]=min⁡(M[i−1,v],min⁡w∈Nv(cwv+M[i−1,w]))M[i,v] = \min \Big( M[i-1, v], \min \limits_{w \in N_v} (c_{wv} + M[i-1, w]) \Big)M[i,v]=min(M[i−1,v],w∈Nv​min​(cwv​+M[i−1,w]))

  • www only needs to range over outgoing neighbors NvN_vNv​ of vvv
  • if nv=∣Nv∣n_v = |N_v|nv​=∣Nv​∣ is the number of outgoing neighbors of vvv, then in each round, we spend time equal to

∑v∈V=m\displaystyle\sum_{v \in V} = mv∈V∑​=m

  • So the total running time can be improved to O(mn)O(mn)O(mn)

Improving the Memory Requirements

M[i,v]=min⁡(M[i−1,v],min⁡w∈Nv(cwv+M[i−1,w]))M[i,v] = \min \Big( M[i-1, v], \min \limits_{w \in N_v} (c_{wv} + M[i-1, w]) \Big)M[i,v]=min(M[i−1,v],w∈Nv​min​(cwv​+M[i−1,w]))

  • However, M[i,v]M[i,v]M[i,v] depends only on M[i−1,∗]M[i-1, *]M[i−1,∗] and no other indices

    • Maintain two arrays MMM and M′M'M′ indexed over VVV
    • At the beginning of each iteration, copy MMM into M′M'M′
    • To update MMM, we use

M[v]=min⁡(M′[v],min⁡w∈Nv(cwv+M′[w]))M[v] = \min \Big( M'[v], \min \limits_{w \in N_v} (c_{wv} + M'[w]) \Big)M[v]=min(M′[v],w∈Nv​min​(cwv​+M′[w]))

  • claim: at the beginning of iteration iii, MMM stores values of OPT(i−1,v)OPT(i - 1, v)OPT(i−1,v) for all nodes v∈Vv \in Vv∈V
  • space used is O(n)O(n)O(n)

Computing the Shortest Path: Algorithm

M[v]=min⁡(M′[v],min⁡w∈Nv(cwv+M′[w]))M[v] = \min \Big( M'[v], \min \limits_{w \in N_v} (c_{wv} + M'[w]) \Big)M[v]=min(M′[v],w∈Nv​min​(cwv​+M′[w]))

  • How can we recover the shortest path that has cose M[v]M[v]M[v]?
  • For each node vvv, compute and update f(v)f(v)f(v), the first node after vvv in the current shortest path from vvv to ttt

  • Updating f(v)f(v)f(v): If xxx is the node that attains the minimum in min⁡w∈Nv(Cvw+M′[w])\min \limits_{w \in N_v} (C_{vw} + M'[w])w∈Nv​min​(Cvw​+M′[w]) and M′[v]>cvx+M′[x]M'[v] > c_{vx} + M'[x]M′[v]>cvx​+M′[x], set

    • M[v]=cvx+M′[x]M[v] = c_{vx} + M'[x]M[v]=cvx​+M′[x]
    • f(v)=xf(v) = xf(v)=x
  • At the end, follow f(v)f(v)f(v) points from s→ts \rightarrow ts→t (and hope for the best lol??)

Computing the Shortest Path: Correctness

  • Pointer graph P(V,F)P(V, F)P(V,F): each edge in FFF is (v,f(v))(v, f(v))(v,f(v))

    • Can PPP have cycles?
    • is there a path from s→ts \rightarrow ts→t in PPP?
    • Can there be multiple paths s→ts \rightarrow ts→t in PPP?
    • Which of these is the shortest path?

Computing the Shortest Path: Cycles in PPP

M[v]=min⁡(M′[v],min⁡w∈Nv(cvw+M′[w]))M[v] = \min \Big(M'[v], \min \limits_{w \in N_v} (c_{vw} + M'[w])\Big)M[v]=min(M′[v],w∈Nv​min​(cvw​+M′[w]))

  • Claim: If PPP has a cycle CCC, then CCC has negative cost.

    • Suppose we set f(v)=wf(v) = wf(v)=w, at this instant M[v]=cwv+M′[w]M[v] = c_{wv} + M'[w]M[v]=cwv​+M′[w]
    • Comparing M[w]M[w]M[w] and M′[w]M'[w]M′[w], we know that M[w]≤M′[w]M[w] \leq M'[w]M[w]≤M′[w]
    • Between this assignment and the assignment of f(v)f(v)f(v) to some other node, M[w]M[w]M[w] may itself decrease. Hence, M[v]≥cwv+M[v]M[v] \geq c_{wv} + M[v]M[v]≥cwv​+M[v], in general
    • Let v1,v2,...,vkv_1, v_2, ..., v_kv1​,v2​,...,vk​ be the nodes in CCC and assume that (vk,v1)(v_k, v_1)(vk​,v1​) is the last edge to have been added.

    • What is the situation just before this addition?

      • M[vi]−M[vi+1]≥cvivi+1M[v_i] - M[v_{i+1}] \geq c_{v_iv_{i+1}}M[vi​]−M[vi+1​]≥cvi​vi+1​​ for all 1≤i<k−11 \leq i < k -11≤i<k−1, f(vi)=vi+1f(v_i) = v_{i+1}f(vi​)=vi+1​
      • M[vk]−M[v1]>cvkv1M[v_k] - M[v_1] > c_{v_kv_1}M[vk​]−M[v1​]>cvk​v1​​
      • Adding all these inequalities: 0>∑i=1k−1cvivi+1+cvkv1=0 > \sum_{i=1}^{k -1} c_{v_iv_{i+1}} + c_{v_kv_1} =0>∑i=1k−1​cvi​vi+1​​+cvk​v1​​= cost of CCC
    • Corollary: if GGG has no negative cycles then PPP does not either

Computing the Shortest Path: Paths in PPP

  • Let PPP be the pointer graph upon termination of the algorithm
  • Consider the path PvP_vPv​ in PPP obtained by following the pointers from vvv to f(v)=v1f(v) = v_1f(v)=v1​ to f(v1)=v2f(v_1) = v_2f(v1​)=v2​ and so on
  • Claim: PvP_vPv​ terminates at ttt
  • Claim PvP_vPv​ is the shortest path in GGG from vvv to ttt

Bellman-For algorithm: One Array

M[v]=min⁡(M[v],min⁡w∈Nv(cvw+M[w]))M[v] = \min \Big( M[v], \min \limits_{w \in N_v} (c_{vw} + M[w]) \Big)M[v]=min(M[v],w∈Nv​min​(cvw​+M[w]))

  • In general, after iii iterations, the path whose length is M[v]M[v]M[v] may have many more than iii edges
  • Early termination: if MMM does not change after processing all the nodes, we have computed all shortest paths to ttt

10 - Network Flow

Motivation

  • Fundemental problems in combinatorial optimization
  • duality between flow and cuts

Flow Networks

  • Use directed graphs to model transport networks:

    • edges carry traffic and have capacities
    • nodes act as switches
    • source nodes generate traffic, sink nodes absorb traffic

  • A flow network is a directed graph G=(V,E)G = (V,E)G=(V,E)

    • each edge e∈Ee \in Ee∈E has a capacity c(e)>0c(e) > 0c(e)>0
    • There is a single source node s∈Vs \in Vs∈V
    • There is a single sink node s∈Vs \in Vs∈V
    • Nodes other than s,ts,ts,t are internal

Defining Flow

  • In a flow network G=(V,E)G = (V,E)G=(V,E), an s−ts-ts−t flow is a function f:E→R+f: E \rightarrow \Reals^+f:E→R+ such that:

    • (Capacity conditions) for each e inE,0≤f(e)≤c(e)e \ in E, 0 \leq f(e) \leq c(e)e inE,0≤f(e)≤c(e)
    • (Conservation conditions) for each internal node vvv, ∑e into Vf(e)=∑e out of Vf(e)\displaystyle\sum_{e \text{ into } V} f(e) = \displaystyle\sum_{e \text{ out of } V} f(e)e into V∑​f(e)=e out of V∑​f(e)
  • The value of a flow is v(f)=∑e out of f(e)v(f) = \sum_{e \text{ out of } } f(e)v(f)=∑e out of ​f(e)

Maximum-Flow Problem

  • Instance: a flow network GGG
  • Solution: The flow with the largest value in GGG, where the maximum is taking over all possible flows on GGG
  • Output should assign a flow value to each edge in the graph
  • The flow on each edge should satisfy the capacity condition
  • The flow into and out of each internal node should satisfy the conservation conditions
  • the value of the output flow, i.e., the total flow out of the source node in the output flow, must be the largest possible over all possible flows in GGG

  • Assumptions:

    • Node edges enter sss, no edges leave ttt
    • There is at least one edge incident on each node
    • all edge capacities are integers

Developing the Algorithm

  • No known DP algorithm

  • Greedy approach instead

    • Start with zero flow along all edges
    • find an s−ts-ts−t path and push as much flow along it as possible
    • idea is to increase flow: push flow along edges with leftover capacity and undow flow along edges already carrying flow

Residual graph

  • Give a flow network G=(V,E)G = (V,E)G=(V,E) and a flow fff on GGG, the residual graph GfG_fGf​ of GGG w.r.t. fff is a directed graph such that:

    • (Nodes) GfG_fGf​ has the same nodes as GGG
    • (Forward edges) for each edge e=(u,v)∈Ee = (u,v) \in Ee=(u,v)∈E s.t. f(e)<c(e)f(e) < c(e)f(e)<c(e), GfG_fGf​ contains the edge (u,v)(u,v)(u,v) with a residual capacity c(e)−f(e)c(e) - f(e)c(e)−f(e)
    • (Backward edges) for each edge e∈Ee \in Ee∈E s.t. f(e)>0f(e) > 0f(e)>0, GfG_fGf​ contains the edge e′=(u,v)e' = (u,v)e′=(u,v) with a residual capacity

Augmenting Paths in a Residual graph

  • Let PPP be a simple s−ts-ts−t path in GfG_fGf​
  • b=bottleneck(P,f)b = bottleneck(P,f)b=bottleneck(P,f) is the minimum residual capacity of any edge in PPP
augment(f,P)Let b=bottleneck(P,f)For (u,v)∈PIf e=(u,v) is a forward edge in Pincrease f(e)∈G by bElse e=(u,v) is a backward edge in Pdecrease f(e)∈G by bReturn f\boxed{ \begin{aligned} &\texttt{augment}(f, P) \\ &\text{Let } b = bottleneck(P, f) \\ &\text{For } (u,v) \in P \\ &\quad\text{If } e = (u,v) \text{ is a forward edge in } P \\ &\qquad\text{increase } f(e) \in G \text{ by } b\\ &\quad\text{Else } e = (u,v) \text{ is a backward edge in } P \\ &\qquad\text{decrease } f(e) \in G \text{ by } b\\ &\text{Return } f \\ \end{aligned} } ​augment(f,P)Let b=bottleneck(P,f)For (u,v)∈PIf e=(u,v) is a forward edge in Pincrease f(e)∈G by bElse e=(u,v) is a backward edge in Pdecrease f(e)∈G by bReturn f​​
  • eee is forward in GfG_fGf​ iff flow increases along e∈Ge \in Ge∈G
  • e=(v,u)e = (v,u)e=(v,u) is backward in GfG_fGf​ iff flow decreases along e=(v,u)∈Ge = (v,u) \in Ge=(v,u)∈G

Correctness of augment(f,P)\texttt{augment}(f,P)augment(f,P)

  • A simple s−ts-ts−t path in the residual graph is an augmenting path
  • Let f′f'f′ be the flow returned by augment(f,P)\texttt{augment}(f,P)augment(f,P)

  • Claim: f′f'f′ is a flow. Verify capacity and conservation conditions

    • Only need to check edges and internal nodes in PPP
    • Capacity condition on e=(u,v)∈Gfe = (u,v) \in G_fe=(u,v)∈Gf​: note that b=bottleneck(P,f)≤b = bottleneck(P,f) \leqb=bottleneck(P,f)≤ residual capacity of (u,v)(u,v)(u,v)
    • eee is a forward edge: 0≤f(e)≤f′(e)=f(e)+b≤f(e)+(c(e)−f(e))=c(e)0 \leq f(e) \leq f'(e) = f(e) + b \leq f(e) + (c(e) - f(e)) = c(e)0≤f(e)≤f′(e)=f(e)+b≤f(e)+(c(e)−f(e))=c(e)

  • eee is a backward edge: c(e)≥f(e)≥f′(e)=f(e)−b≥f(e)−f(e)=0c(e) \geq f(e) \geq f'(e) = f(e) - b \geq f(e) - f(e) = 0c(e)≥f(e)≥f′(e)=f(e)−b≥f(e)−f(e)=0

  • Conservation condition on internal node v∈Pv \in Pv∈P – four cases to work out:

Ford-Fulkerson Algorithm

Max-Flow(G)Initiallyf(e)=0∀e∈Gwhile there is an s-t path in the residual graph GfLet P be a simple s-t path in Gff′=augment(f,P)f←f′Gf←Gf′Return f\boxed{ \begin{aligned} &\texttt{Max-Flow}(G) \\ &\text{Initially} f(e) = 0 \quad \forall e \in G \\ &\text{while there is an s-t path in the residual graph } G_f \\ &\quad\text{Let } P \text{ be a simple s-t path in } G_f \\ &\quad f' = \texttt{augment}(f, P) \\ &\quad f \leftarrow f' \\ &\quad G_f \leftarrow G_{f'} \\ &\text{Return } f \\ \end{aligned} } ​Max-Flow(G)Initiallyf(e)=0∀e∈Gwhile there is an s-t path in the residual graph Gf​Let P be a simple s-t path in Gf​f′=augment(f,P)f←f′Gf​←Gf′​Return f​​
  • Does it terminate? What is it doing?

  • We can see here, the max flow path is s−d−b−c−ts-d-b-c-ts−d−b−c−t, with a bottleneck of b=10b=10b=10 along, that b−db-db−d edge gets augmented
  • Repeat

Analysis of the Ford-Faulkerson Algorithm

  • Running time:

    • Does it terminate? If so, how many loops, since each loop is O(m)O(m)O(m)
  • Claim at each stage, flow values and residual capacities are integers. Prove by induction

  • Claim: Flow value strictly increase when we apply augment(f,p)\texttt{augment}(f,p)augment(f,p)

    • v′(f)=v(f)+bottleneck(P,f)>v(f)v'(f) = v(f) + bottleneck(P,f) > v(f)v′(f)=v(f)+bottleneck(P,f)>v(f)
    • recall every edge that is incident on sss is a forward edge
    • the flow along these edges will increase by bbb
  • Claim : Maximum value of any flow C=∑e out of sc(e)C = \sum_{e \text{ out of } s} c(e)C=∑e out of s​c(e)
  • Claim: Algorithm terminates in at most CCC iterations
  • Claim: Algorithm runs in O(mC)O(mC)O(mC) time

Correctness of the Ford-Faulkerson Algorithm

  • How large can the flow be?
  • Can we characterise the magnitude of the flow in terms of the structure of the graph? For example, for every flow f,v(f)≤C=∑e out of sc(e)f, v(f) \leq C = \sum_{e \text{ out of } s} c(e)f,v(f)≤C=∑e out of s​c(e)
  • Is there a better bound?

  • Proof strategy:

    • Define s−ts-ts−t cut, its capacity, and flow in and out of the cut
    • For any s−ts-ts−t cut, prove any flow ≤\leq≤ its capacity
    • Define a specific s−ts-ts−t cut at the end of the Ford-Faulkerson algorithm
    • Prove that the flow across this cut equals its capacity

s−ts-ts−t Cuts and Capacities

  • An s−ts-ts−t cut is a partition of VVV into sets AAA and BBB such that s∈As \in As∈A and t∈Bt \in Bt∈B
  • Capacity of the cut(A,B)cut(A, B)cut(A,B) is

c(A,B)=∑e out of Ac(e)c(A,B) = \displaystyle\sum_{e \text{ out of } A} c(e)c(A,B)=e out of A∑​c(e)

  • Intuition: For every flow f,v(f)≤c(A,B)f, v(f) \leq c(A,B)f,v(f)≤c(A,B)

Fun Facts about Cuts

  • Let fff be any s−ts-ts−t flow and (A,B)(A,B)(A,B) any s−ts-ts−t cut

  • Claim: f(v)=fout(A)−fin(A)f(v) = f_{out}(A) - f_{in}(A)f(v)=fout​(A)−fin​(A)

    • v(f)=fout(s)v(f) = f_{out}(s)v(f)=fout​(s) and fin(s)=0⇒v(f)=fout(s)−fin(s)f_{in}(s) = 0 \rArr v(f) = f_{out}(s) - f_{in}(s)fin​(s)=0⇒v(f)=fout​(s)−fin​(s)
    • For ever other node v∈Av \in Av∈A, 0=fout(v)−fin(v)0 = f_{out}(v) - f_{in}(v)0=fout​(v)−fin​(v)

    • Summing up all these equations, v(f)=∑v∈A(fout(v)−fin(v)v(f) = \sum_{v \in A}(f_{out}(v) - f_{in}(v)v(f)=∑v∈A​(fout​(v)−fin​(v)

      • An edge eee that has both ends in AAA or both ends out of AAA does not contribute
      • An edge eee that has its tail in AAA contributes f(e)f(e)f(e)
      • An edge eee that has its head in AAA contributes −f(e)-f(e)−f(e)
    • ∑v∈A(fout(v)−fin(v)=∑e out of Af(e)−∑e into Af(e)=fout(A)−fin(A)\sum_{v \in A} (f_{out}(v) - f_{in}(v) = \sum_{e \text { out of } A} f(e) - \sum_{e \text{ into A} } f(e) = f_{out}(A) - f_{in}(A)∑v∈A​(fout​(v)−fin​(v)=∑e out of A​f(e)−∑e into A​f(e)=fout​(A)−fin​(A)
  • Corollary: v(f)=fin(B)−fout(B)v(f) = f_{in}(B) - f_{out}(B)v(f)=fin​(B)−fout​(B)

Important Fact about Cuts

  • v(f)≤c(A,B)v(f) \leq c(A,B)v(f)≤c(A,B)
v(f)=fout(A)−fin(A)≤fout=∑e out ofAf(e)≤∑e out ofAc(e)=c(A,B)\begin{aligned} v(f) &= f_{out}(A) - f_{in}(A) \\ &\leq f_{out} = \displaystyle\sum_{e \text{ out of} A} f(e) \\ &\leq \displaystyle\sum_{e \text{ out of} A} c(e) = c(A,B) \end{aligned}v(f)​=fout​(A)−fin​(A)≤fout​=e out ofA∑​f(e)≤e out ofA∑​c(e)=c(A,B)​

Max-Flows and Min-Cuts

  • Let fff be any s−ts-ts−t flow and (A,B)(A,B)(A,B) any s−ts-ts−t cut. We proved v(f)≤c(A,B)v(f) \leq c(A,B)v(f)≤c(A,B)
  • Very strong statement: The value of every flow is ≤\leq≤ capacity of any cut
  • Corollary: The maximum flow is at most the smallest capacity of a cut
  • Question: Is the reverse true? Is the smallest capacity of a cut at most the maximum flow
  • Answer: Yes, the Ford-Faulkerson algorithm computes this cut!

Flows and Cuts

  • Let f‾\overline ff​ denote the flow computed by the Ford-Faulkerson algorithm
  • Enough to show ∃s−t\exist s-t∃s−t cut (A∗,B∗)(A^*,B^*)(A∗,B∗) such that v(f‾)=c(A∗,B∗)v(\overline f) = c(A^*, B^*)v(f​)=c(A∗,B∗)
  • When the algorithm terminates, the residual graph has no s−ts-ts−t path

  • Claim: If fff is an s−ts-ts−t flow such that GfG_fGf​ has no s−ts-ts−t path, then there is an s−ts-ts−t cut (A∗,B∗(A^*, B^*(A∗,B∗ such that v(f)=c(A∗,B∗)v(f) = c(A^*, B^*)v(f)=c(A∗,B∗)

    • Claim applies to any flow fff such that GfG_fGf​ has no s−ts-ts−t path, and not just to the flow f‾\overline ff​ computed by the Ford-Faulkerson algorithm

Proof of Claim Relating Flows to Cuts

  • Claim: fff is an s−ts-ts−t flow and GfG_fGf​ has no s−ts-ts−t path ⇒∃s−t\rArr \exist s-t⇒∃s−t cut (A∗,B∗),v(f)=c(A∗,B∗)(A^*,B^*), v(f) = c(A^*,B^*)(A∗,B∗),v(f)=c(A∗,B∗)
  • A∗=A^* =A∗= set of nodes reachable from sss in Gf,B∗=V−A∗G_f, B^* = V - A^*Gf​,B∗=V−A∗
  • Claim: (A∗,B∗)(A^*,B^*)(A∗,B∗) is an s−ts-ts−t cut in GGG
  • Claim: If e=(u,v)e = (u,v)e=(u,v) such that u∈A∗,v∈B∗u \in A^*, v \in B^*u∈A∗,v∈B∗, then f(e)=c(e)f(e) = c(e)f(e)=c(e)
  • Claim: If e′=(u′,v′)e' = (u', v')e′=(u′,v′) such that u′∈B∗,v′∈A∗u' \in B^*, v' \in A^*u′∈B∗,v′∈A∗, then f(e′)=0f(e') = 0f(e′)=0
  • Claim v(f)=c(A∗,B∗)v(f) = c(A^*, B^*)v(f)=c(A∗,B∗)
v(f)=fout(A∗)−fin(A∗)=∑e out of A∗f(e)−∑e into A∗f(e)=∑e out of A∗c(e)−∑e into A∗0=c(A∗,B∗)\begin{aligned} v(f) &= f_{out}(A^*) - f_{in}(A^*) \\ &= \displaystyle\sum_{e \text{ out of } A^*} f(e) - \displaystyle\sum_{e \text{ into } A^*} f(e) \\ &= \displaystyle\sum_{e \text{ out of } A^*} c(e) - \displaystyle\sum_{e \text{ into } A^*} 0 \\ &= c(A^*, B^*) \\ \end{aligned}v(f)​=fout​(A∗)−fin​(A∗)=e out of A∗∑​f(e)−e into A∗∑​f(e)=e out of A∗∑​c(e)−e into A∗∑​0=c(A∗,B∗)​

Max-Flow Min-Cut Theorem

  • The flow f‾\overline ff​ computed by the Ford-Faulkerson algorithm is a maximum flow
  • Given a flow of maximum value, we can compute a minimum s−ts-ts−t cut in O(m)O(m)O(m) time
  • In every flow network, there is a flow fff and a cut (A,B)(A,B)(A,B) such that v(f)=c(A,B)v(f) = c(A,B)v(f)=c(A,B)
  • Max-Flow Min-Cut Theorem: in every flow network, the maximum value of an s−ts-ts−t flow is equal to the minimum capacity of an s−ts-ts−t cut
  • Corollary: If all capacities in a flow network are integers, then there is a maximum flow fff where f(e)f(e)f(e), the value of the flow on edge eee, is an integer for every edge e∈Ge \in Ge∈G

Real-Valued Capacities

  • If capacities are real-valued, Ford-Faulkerson algorithm may not terminate!
  • But Max-Flow Min-Cut theorem is still true, why?

Improving Ford-Faulkerson Algorithm

  • Bad case for Ford-Faulkerson is when the bottleneck edge is the augmenting path has a low capacity
  • Idea: decrease number of iterations by picking s−ts-ts−t path with bottleneck edge of largest capacity. Computing this path can slow down each iteration considerably.
  • Modified idea: Maintain a scaling parameter Δ\DeltaΔ and choose only augmenting paths with bottleneck capacity at least Δ\DeltaΔ
  • Gf(Δ)G_f(\Delta)Gf​(Δ): residual network restricted to edges with residual capacities ≥Δ\geq \Delta≥Δ

11 - Network Flow Applications

Maximum Flow and Minimum Cut Problems

Matching in Bipartite Graphs

  • Bipartite Graph a graph G(V,E)G(V,E)G(V,E) where

    • V=X∪Y,X,YV = X \cup Y, X,YV=X∪Y,X,Y are disjoint and
    • E⊆X×YE \subseteq X \times YE⊆X×Y
  • Bipartite graphs model situations in which objects are matched with or assigned to other objects: e.g. marraiges, residents/hospitals, jobs/machines
  • A Matching in a bipartite graph GGG is a set M⊆M \subseteqM⊆ of edges such that each node of VVV is incident on at most edge of MMM
  • A set of edges MMM is a perfect matching if every node in VVV is incident on exactly one edge in MMM
  • Instance: A bipartite graph GGG
  • Solution: The matching of largest size in GGG

Algorithm for Bipartite Graph Matching

  • Convert GGG to a flow network G′G'G′: direct edges from XXX to YYY, add nodes sss and ttt connect sss to each node in XXX and ttt to each node in yyy, set all edge capacities to 1
  • Computer the maximum flow in G′G'G′
  • Convert the maximum flow in G′G'G′ into a matching in GGG
  • Claim: the value of the maximum flow in G′G'G′ equals the size of hte maximum matching in GGG
  • In general, there is a matching of size kkk in GGG if an only if there is a (integer valued) flow of kkk in G′G'G′

Strategy for Proving Correctness

  • Preclude the possibilities that G′G'G′ has a flow of value kkk but we cannot construct a matching in GGG with kkk edges
  • Matching => flow: if there is a matching with kkk edges in GGG, there is an s−ts-ts−t flow of value kkk in G′G'G′

  • How do we construct this flow?

    • Consider every edge (u,v)(u,v)(u,v) in the matching: u∈X,v∈Yu \in X, v \in Yu∈X,v∈Y
    • Send on unit of flow along the path s→u→v→ts \rightarrow u \rightarrow v \rightarrow ts→u→v→t

  • Why have we constructed a flow

    • Capacity constraint: No edges receive a flow >1> 1>1 because we started with a matching
    • Conservation constraint: Every node other than sss and ttt has one incoming unit and one outgoing unit of flow because we started with a matching
  • What is the value of the flow? kkk, since exactly that many nodes out of sss carry flow

Now let us consider the reverse side of the reduction

  • Flow => matching: if there is a flow f′f'f′ in G′G'G′ with value kkk, there is a matching MMM in GGG with kkk edges

    • There is an integer-valued flow f′f'f′ of value k  ⟹  k \impliesk⟹ flow along any edge is 0 or 1
    • Let MMM be the set of edges not incident on sss or ttt with flow equal to 1
    • Claim: MMM contains kkk edges
    • Claim Each node in XXX (respectively, YYY) is the tail (respectively, head) of at most one edge in MMM
  • Conclusion: size of the maximum matching in GGG is equal to the value of the maximum flow in G′G'G′: the edges in this matching are those that carry flow from XXX to YYY in G′G'G′

In general, we must prove that the reduction is bi-directional, or isomorphic

Running time of Bipartite Graph Matching Algorithm

  • Suppose GGG has mmm edges in nnn nodes in XXX, and in YYY
  • C≤nC \leq nC≤n
  • Ford-Fulkerson algorithm runs in O(mn)O(mn)O(mn) time
  • How do we determine if a bipartite graph GGG has a perfect matching? Find the maximum matching and check if it is perfect
  • Suppose GGG has no perfect matching. Can we exhibit a short "certificate" of that fact? What can such certificates look like?
  • GGG has no perfect matching iff there is a cut in G′G'G′ with capacity less than nnn. Therefore, the cut is a certificate

  • We would like the certificate in terms of GGG

    • For example, two nodes in YYY with on incident edge each with the same neighbor in XXX
    • Generally, a subset S⊆XS \subseteq XS⊆X with neighbors Γ(A)⊆Y\Gamma (A) \subseteq YΓ(A)⊆Y, such that ∣A∣<∣Γ(A)∣|A| < |\Gamma(A)|∣A∣<∣Γ(A)∣

  • Hall's Theorem Let G(X∪Y,E)G(X \cup Y, E)G(X∪Y,E) be a bipartite graph such that ∣X∣=∣Y∣|X| = |Y|∣X∣=∣Y∣. Then GGG either has a perfect matching or there is a subset A⊆YA \subseteq YA⊆Y such that ∣A∣>∣Γ(A)∣|A| > | \Gamma (A) |∣A∣>∣Γ(A)∣. We can compute a perfect matching or such a subset in O(mn)O(mn)O(mn) time.

    • Γ(x5)={y4,y5}\Gamma (x_5) = \{y_4, y_5\}Γ(x5​)={y4​,y5​}, the neighbors of x5x_5x5​

Edge-Disjoint Paths

  • A set of paths in a directed graph GGG is edge disjoint if each edge in GGG appears in at most one path
  • Instance: Directed graph G(V,E)G(V,E)G(V,E) with two distinguished nodes s,ts,ts,t
  • Solution: The maximum number of edge-disjoiint paths between sss and ttt

Mapping to the Max-Flow Problem

  • Convert GGG into a flow network with edge capacities of 1
  • Claim: There are kkk edge-disjoint s−ts-ts−t paths from in a directed graph GGG if and only if there is a s−ts-ts−t flow in GGG with value ≥k\geq k≥k
  • Paths => flow: if there are kkk edge-disjoint paths from sss to ttt, send one unit of flowin along each to yield a flow with value kkk

  • Flow => paths: Suppose there is an integer-valued flow of value at least kkk. Are there kkk edge-disjoint paths? If so, what are they?

    • There is an integral flow. Therefore flow on each edge is 0, or 1
    • Claim: if fff is a 0-1 value flow of value v(f)=kv(f) = kv(f)=k, the the set of edges with flow f(e)=1f(e) = 1f(e)=1 contains a set of kkk edge-disjoint paths

  • But how do we show that this set of edges with flow value of 1 actually form paths?

    • Claim if fff is a 0−10-10−1 valued flow of value v(f)=kv(f) = kv(f)=km then the set of edges with flow f(e)=1f(e) = 1f(e)=1 contains a set of kkk edge-disjoint paths

  • Prove by induction on the number of edges in fff that carry flow. Let this number be κ(f)\kappa(f)κ(f).

    • Base case: v=0v = 0v=0. Nothing to prove

    • Inductive Hypothesis: For every flow f′f'f′ in GGG with

      • value v(f′)<kv(f') < kv(f′)<k carrying flow on κ(f′)<κ(f)\kappa (f') < \kappa (f)κ(f′)<κ(f) edges or
      • value v(f′)=kv(f') = kv(f′)=k carrying flow on κ(f′)<κ(f)\kappa (f') < \kappa (f)κ(f′)<κ(f) edges, the set of edges with f′(e)=1f'(e) = 1f′(e)=1 contains a set of v(f′)v(f')v(f′) edge-disjoint s−ts-ts−t paths
    • Inductive Step: Construct a set of kkk s−ts-ts−t paths from fff. Work out by hand
  • Note: formulating the inductive hypothesis can be trick
  • Strategy is to prove the inductive step first

  • During this proof, we observe two types of "smaller" flows:

    • When you succeed in finding an s−ts-ts−t path, we get a new flow f′f'f′ that is smaller, i.e. v(f′)<kv(f') < kv(f′)<k carrying flow on fewer edges, i.e. κ(f′)<κ(f)\kappa (f') < \kappa (f)κ(f′)<κ(f)
    • When we run into a cycle, we get a new flow f′f'f′ with v(f′)=kv(f') = kv(f′)=k but carrying flow on fewer edges, i.e. κ(f′)<κ(f)\kappa (f') < \kappa (f)κ(f′)<κ(f)
  • We combine both situations in the inductive hypothesis

Certificate for Edge-Disjoint Paths Algorithm

  • A set F⊆EF \subseteq EF⊆E of edges separatees s,ts,ts,t if the graph (V,E−F)(V, E-F)(V,E−F) contains no s−ts-ts−t paths
  • Menger's Theorem: In every directed graph with nodes s,ts,ts,t, the maximum number of edge disjoint s−ts-ts−t paths is equal to the minimum number of edges whose removal disconnes sss from ttt.

Running Time of the Edge-Disjoint Paths Algorithm

  • Given a flow of value kkk, how quickly can we determine the kkk edge-disjoint paths? O(mn)O(mn)O(mn)
  • Corollary: The Ford-Fulkerson algorithm can be used to find a maximum set of edge-disjoint s−ts-ts−t paths in a directed graph GGG in O(mn)O(mn)O(mn) time.

Edge-Disjoint Paths in Undirected Graphs

  • Can extend the theorem to undirected graphs
  • Replace each edge with two directed edges of capacity 1 and apply the algorithm for directed graphs

  • Problem: Both counterparts of an undirected edge (u,v)(u,v)(u,v) may be used by differnt edge-disjoint paths on the directed graph

    • resolved by zeroing out flow for edges where flow goes in both directions
  • Can obtain an integral flow where only one of the directed counterparts of (u,v)(u,v)(u,v) has non-zero flow
  • We can find the maximum number of edge disjoint paths in O(mn)O(mn)O(mn) time
  • We can prove a version of Menger's theorem for undirected graphs: in every undirected graph with nodes s,ts,ts,t, the maximum number of edge-disjoint s−ts-ts−t paths is equal to the minimum number of edges whose removal separates sss from ttt

Image Segmentation

  • Fundemental problem in computer vision: segmentaing an image into coherent regions
  • A basic segmentation problem is that of partitioning an image into a foreground and a background: label each pixel in the image as belonging to one of those two
  • Let VVV be the set of pixels in an image
  • Let EEE be the set of pairs of neighboring pixels
  • VVV and EEE yield an undirected graph G(V,E)G(V,E)G(V,E)
  • Each pixel iii has a likelihood ai>0a_i > 0ai​>0 that it belongs to the foreground and a likelihood bib_ibi​ that it belongs to the background
  • These likelihoods are specified in the input to the problem
  • We want to fg/bg boundary to be smooth: for each pait (i,j)(i,j)(i,j) of pixels, there is a separation penalty pij≥0p_{ij} \geq 0pij​≥0 for placing one of them in the foreground and the other in the background

Formulating the Problem

  • Instance: Pixel graphs G(V,E)G(V,E)G(V,E), likelihood functions a,b:V→R+a,b: V \rightarrow \Reals^+a,b:V→R+, penalty function p:E→R+p: E \rightarrow \Reals^+p:E→R+
  • Solution: Optimum labelling: partition of the pixels into two sets A,BA,BA,B that maximizes
q(A,B)=∑i∈Aai+∑j∈Bbi−∑(i,j)∈E∣A∩{i,j}∣=1pij\begin{aligned} q(A,B) &= \displaystyle\sum_{i \in A} a_i + \displaystyle\sum_{j \in B} b_i - \displaystyle\sum_{ (i,j) \in E |A \cap \{i,j\}|=1 } p_{ij} \end{aligned}q(A,B)​=i∈A∑​ai​+j∈B∑​bi​−(i,j)∈E∣A∩{i,j}∣=1∑​pij​​
  • There is a similarity between cuts and labellings

  • Differences:

    • Maximizing an objective function rather than minimizing
    • There is no source or sink in the segmentation problem
    • We have values on the nodes
    • The graph is undirected

Maximization to Minimization

  • Let Q−∑i(ai+bi)Q - \sum_i (a_i + b_i)Q−∑i​(ai​+bi​)
  • Notice that ∑i∈Aai∑j∈Bbj=Q−∑i∈Abi−∑j∈Baj\sum_{i \in A} a_i \sum_{j \in B} b_j = Q - \sum_{i \in A} b_i - \sum_{j \in B} a_j∑i∈A​ai​∑j∈B​bj​=Q−∑i∈A​bi​−∑j∈B​aj​
  • Therefore, maximizing
q(A,B)=∑i∈Aai+∑j∈Bbi−∑(i,j)∈E∣A∩{i,j}∣=1pij=Q−∑i∈Abi−∑j∈Baj−∑(i,j)∈E∣A∩{i,j}∣=1pij\begin{aligned} q(A,B) &= \displaystyle\sum_{i \in A} a_i + \displaystyle\sum_{j \in B} b_i - \displaystyle\sum_{ (i,j) \in E |A \cap \{i,j\}|=1 } p_{ij} \\ &= Q - \sum_{i \in A} b_i - \sum_{j \in B} a_j - \displaystyle\sum_{ (i,j) \in E |A \cap \{i,j\}|=1 } p_{ij} \end{aligned}q(A,B)​=i∈A∑​ai​+j∈B∑​bi​−(i,j)∈E∣A∩{i,j}∣=1∑​pij​=Q−i∈A∑​bi​−j∈B∑​aj​−(i,j)∈E∣A∩{i,j}∣=1∑​pij​​

is identical to minimizing

q′(A,B)=∑i∈Abi+∑j∈Baj+∑(i,j)∈E∣A∩{i,j}∣=1pij\begin{aligned} q'(A,B) &= \sum_{i \in A} b_i + \sum_{j \in B} a_j + \displaystyle\sum_{ (i,j) \in E |A \cap \{i,j\}|=1 } p_{ij} \end{aligned}q′(A,B)​=i∈A∑​bi​+j∈B∑​aj​+(i,j)∈E∣A∩{i,j}∣=1∑​pij​​

Solving the Other Issues

  • Solve the other issues like we did earlier:

    • Add a new "super-source" sss to represent foreground
    • Add a new "super-sink" ttt to represent the background
    • Connect s,ts,ts,t to every pixel and assign capacity aia_iai​ to edge (s,i)(s, i)(s,i) and capacity bib_ibi​ to edge (i,t)(i,t)(i,t)
    • Direct edges away from sss and into ttt
    • Replace each edge (i,j)(i,j)(i,j) in EEE with two directed edges of capacity pijp_{ij}pij​
  • Now we want the minimum capacity s−ts-ts−t cut

Cuts in the Flow Network

  • Let G′G'G′ be this flow network and (A,B)(A,B)(A,B) and s−ts-ts−t cut
  • What does the capacity of the cut represent?

  • Edges crossing the cut can be one of three types:

    • (s,w),w∈B(s,w), w \in B(s,w),w∈B contributes to awa_waw​
    • (u,t),u∈A(u,t), u \in A(u,t),u∈A contributes to bub_ubu​
    • (u,w),u∈A,w∈B(u,w), u \in A, w \in B(u,w),u∈A,w∈B contributes to puwp_{uw}puw​
c(A,B)=∑i∈Abi+∑j∈Baj+∑(i,j)∈E∣A∩{i,j}∣=1pij=q′(A,B)\begin{aligned} c(A,B) &= \displaystyle\sum_{i \in A} b_i + \displaystyle\sum_{j \in B} a_j + \displaystyle\sum_{ (i,j) \in E |A \cap \{i,j\}|=1 } p_{ij} = q'(A,B) \end{aligned}c(A,B)​=i∈A∑​bi​+j∈B∑​aj​+(i,j)∈E∣A∩{i,j}∣=1∑​pij​=q′(A,B)​
  • So, the capacity of an s−ts-ts−t cut c(A,B)c(A,B)c(A,B) exactly measure the quantity q′(A,B)q'(A,B)q′(A,B)
  • To maximise q(A,B)q(A,B)q(A,B), we compute the s−ts-ts−t cut (A,B)(A,B)(A,B) of minimum capacity
  • Deleting s,ts,ts,t from the cut yields the desired segmentation of the image
  • Thus, Image Segmentation is reduced to a Minimum Cut problem

12 - NP and Computational Intractibility

  • N=1,P=0N = 1, P = 0N=1,P=0

Algorithm Design

  • Patterns:

    • Greed O(nlog⁡n)O(n \log n)O(nlogn) interval scheduling
    • Divide and Conquer O(nlog⁡n)O(n \log n)O(nlogn) counting inversions
    • Dynamic Programmming O(n3)O(n^3)O(n3) RNA folding
    • Duality: O(n2m)O(n^2 m)O(n2m) maximum flow and minimum cuts
    • Reductions
    • Local search
    • Randomization

  • Anti-Patterns

    • NP-completeness: O(nk)O(n^k)O(nk) algorithm unlikely
    • PSPACE-completeness: O(nk)O(n^k)O(nk) certification algorithm unlikely
    • Undecidability: no algorithm possible

Computational Tractability

  • When is an algorithm an efficient solution to a problem? When the running time is polynomial in the size of the input
  • A problem is computationally tractable if it has a polynomial time algorithm solution
Polynomial time Probably not
Shortest path Longest Path
Matching 3D Matching
Min cut Max cut
2-SAT 3 SAT
Planar four-color Planar 3 color
Bipartite vertex cover vertex cover
Primarily testing Factoring

Problem Classification

  • Classify problems based on whether they admit efficient solutions or not
  • Some extremely hard problems cannot be solved efficiently (e.g. chess on an n×nn \times nn×n board)
  • However, classification is unclear for a large number of problems
  • We can prove that these problems are fundementally equivalent and are manifestations of the same problem!

Polynomial-Time Reduction

  • Goal is to express statements of the type: "Problem X is at least as hard as problem Y"
  • Use the notion of reductions

  • Y is polynomial-time reducible to XXX (Y≤PX)(Y \leq_P X)(Y≤P​X) if any arbitrary instance (input) of YYY can be solved using a polynomial number of standard operations, plus one call to a black box that solves problem XXX

    • Maximum Bipartite Matching ≤P\leq_P≤P​ Maxmum s−ts-ts−t Flow

      • Maximum Bipartite Matching ≰P\nleq_P≰P​ Maxmum s−ts-ts−t Flow because you can't reduce a network flow to a bipartite matching...
      • You can get 4 from 3 by adding 1, but you can't get 3 from 4 by adding 1
    • Image Segmentation ≤P\leq_P≤P​ Minimum s−ts-ts−t Cut
    • ≤P=\leq_P =≤P​= polynomial time reducable
  • Y≤PXY \leq_P XY≤P​X implies that "XXX is at least as hard as YYY"
  • Such reductions are Karp reductions. Cook reductions allow a polynomial number of calls to the black box that solves XXX

Usefulness of Reductions

  • Claim: If Y≤PXY \leq_P XY≤P​X and XXX can be solved in polynomial time, then YYY can be solved in polynomial time
  • Contrapositive: If Y≤PXY \leq_P XY≤P​X and YYY cannot be solved in polynomial time, then XXX cannot be solved in polynomial time
  • Informally: If YYY is hard, and we can show that YYY reduces to XXX, then the hardness "spreads" to XXX

Reduction Strategies

  • Simple equivalence
  • Special case to general case
  • Encoding with gadgets

Optimisiation versus Decision Problems

  • So far, we have developed algorithms that solve optimisation problems

    • Compute the largest flow
    • Find the closest pair of points
    • Find the schedule with the least completion time
  • Now, we turn our attention to decision versions of problems, e.g. is there a flow with value at least kkk, for a given value of kkk
  • Decision problem: answer to every input is yes or no

Primes

  • Instance: A natural number nnn
  • Question: Is nnn prime?

Independent Set and Vertex Cover

  • Given an undirected graph G=(V,E)G = (V,E)G=(V,E), a subset S⊆VS \subseteq VS⊆V is an independent set if no two vertices in SSS are connected by an edge

    • Instance: Undirected graph GGG and an integer kkk
    • Question: Does GGG contain an independent set of size ≥k\geq k≥k

  • Given an undirected graph G=(V,E)G = (V,E)G=(V,E), a subset S⊆VS \subseteq VS⊆V is a vertex cover if every edge in EEE is incident on at least one vertex in SSS

    • Instance: Undirected graph GGG and an integer kkk
    • Question: Does GGG contain a vertx cover of size ≥k\geq k≥k
  • Goal: Demonstrate a simple equivalence between these two problems
  • Claim: Independent Set ≤P\leq_P≤P​ Vertex Cover and Vertex Cover ≤P\leq_P≤P​ Independent Set
  • N.B. the inverse of an independent set must be a vertex cover

Strategy for Proving Independent Set ≤P\leq_P≤P​ Vertex Cover

  • Start with an arbitrary instance of IS: an undirected graph G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E) and an integer kkk
  • From G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E) and kkk, create an instance of VC: an undirected graph G′=(V′,E′)G'=(V', E')G′=(V′,E′) and an integer k′k'k′
  • G′G'G′ is related to GGG in some way
  • k′k'k′ can depend upon kkk and size of GGG
  • Prove that G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E) has an IS of size ≥k\geq k≥k iff G′G'G′ has a vertex cover of size ≤k′\leq k'≤k′

  • Transformation and proof must be correct for all possible graphs GGG and all possible values of kkk

    • This proof is an iff because we're using a blackbox algorithm for VC to solve IS

      • If there is an independent set size ≥k\geq k≥k, we must be sure that there is a vertex cover of size ≤k′\leq k'≤k′, so that we know that the black box will find this vertex cover
      • If the black box finds a vertex cover of size ≤k′\leq k'≤k′, we must be sure we can construct an independent set of size ≥k\geq k≥k from this vertex cover
  • Arbitrary instance of IS: G,kG, kG,k
  • Let ∣V∣=n|V| = n∣V∣=n
  • Create an instance of VC: G,k′=n−kG, k' = n - kG,k′=n−k
  • Claim: GGG has an IS of size ≥k\geq k≥k iff GGG has a VC of size ≤n−k\leq n - k≤n−k
  • Proof: SSS is an IS in GGG iff V−SV-SV−S is a VC in G
  • The same idea proces that VC ≤P\leq_P≤P​ IS

Vertex Cover and Set Cover

  • IS is a "packing" problem: pack as many vertices as possible, subject to constraints (the edges)
  • VC is a "covering" problem: cover all edges in the graph with as few vertices as possible

Microbe Cover

  • Instance: A set UUU of nnn compounds, a collection M1,M2,...,MlM_1, M_2, ..., M_lM1​,M2​,...,Ml​ of microbes, where each microbe can make a subset of compounds in UUU, and an integer kkk
  • Question: Is there a subset of ≤k\leq k≤k microbes that can together make all the compounds in UUU?

Vertex Cover ≤P\leq_P≤P​ Microbe Cover

  • Input to VC: an undirected graph G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E) and an integer kkk
  • Let ∣V∣=l|V| = l∣V∣=l

  • Create an instance {U,{M1,M2,...,Ml}}\{U, \{ M_1, M_2, ..., M_l\} \}{U,{M1​,M2​,...,Ml​}} of Microbe cover where:

    • U=EU = EU=E, i.e. each element of UUU is an edge of GGG
    • For each node i∈Vi \in Vi∈V, create a microbe MiM_iMi​ whose compounds are the set of edges incident on iii
  • Claim: UUU can be covered with ≤k\leq k≤k microbes iff GGG has a VC cover with ≤k\leq k≤k nodes

  • Proof strategy:

    • If GGG has a VC of size ≤k\leq k≤k, then UUU can be covered with ≤k\leq k≤k
    • If UUU can be covered with ≤k\leq k≤k microbes, then GGG has a vertex cover of size ≤k\leq k≤k

  • this is a different form of the Set Cover problem:

    • Instance: A set UUU of nnn elements, a collection S1,S2,...,SmS_1, S_2, ..., S_mS1​,S2​,...,Sm​ of subsets of UUU, and an integer kkk
    • Question: Is there a collection of ≤k\leq k≤k sets in the collections whose union is UUU?

Boolean Satisfiability

  • Abstract problems formulated in Boolean notation
  • given a set X={x1,x2,...,xn}X = \{ x_1, x_2, ..., x_n\}X={x1​,x2​,...,xn​} of nnn Boolean variables
  • Each term can take the value of 0,10,10,1
  • Term: a variable xix_ixi​ or its negation xiˉ\bar{x_i}xi​ˉ​
  • Cause of Length: (or) lll distinct terms t1∨t2∨...tlt_1 \lor t_2 \lor ... t_lt1​∨t2​∨...tl​
  • Truth assignment for XXX: is a function v:X→{0,1}v: X \rightarrow \{ 0,1 \}v:X→{0,1}
  • An assignment vvv satisfies a clause CCC if it causes at least one term in CCC to evaluate to 1 (since CCC is an or of terms)

  • An assignment satisfies a collection of clauses C1,C2,...,CkC_1, C_2, ..., C_kC1​,C2​,...,Ck​ if it causes all clauses to evaluate to 1 i.e. C1∧C2∧...Ck=1C_1 \land C_2 \land ... C_k = 1C1​∧C2​∧...Ck​=1

    • vvv is a satisfying assignment with respect to C1,C2,...,CkC_1, C_2, ..., C_kC1​,C2​,...,Ck​
    • set of clauses C1,C2,...,CkC_1, C_2, ..., C_kC1​,C2​,...,Ck​ is satisfiable

Examples

  • X={x1,x2,x3,x4}X = \{ x_1, x_2, x_3, x_4\}X={x1​,x2​,x3​,x4​}
  • Terms: x1,x1ˉ,x2,x2ˉ,x3,x3ˉ,x4,x4ˉ,x_1, \bar{x_1}, x_2, \bar{x_2}, x_3, \bar{x_3}, x_4, \bar{x_4},x1​,x1​ˉ​,x2​,x2​ˉ​,x3​,x3​ˉ​,x4​,x4​ˉ​,

  • Clauses:

    • x1∨x2ˉ∨x3ˉx_1 \lor \bar{x_2} \lor \bar{x_3}x1​∨x2​ˉ​∨x3​ˉ​
    • x2∨x3ˉ∨x4x_2 \lor \bar{x_3} \lor x_4x2​∨x3​ˉ​∨x4​
    • x3∨x4ˉx_3 \lor \bar{x_4}x3​∨x4​ˉ​

  • Assignment: x1=1,x2=0,x3=1,x4=0x_1 = 1, x_2 = 0, x_3 = 1, x_4 = 0x1​=1,x2​=0,x3​=1,x4​=0

    • Not satisfying because of clauses 1, 3

  • Assignment: x1=1,x2=0,x3=1,x4=0x_1 = 1, x_2 = 0, x_3 = 1, x_4 = 0x1​=1,x2​=0,x3​=1,x4​=0

    • is satisfying

SAT and 3-SAT

  • Instance: A set of clauses C1,C2,...,CkC_1, C_2, ..., C_kC1​,C2​,...,Ck​, each of length 3, over a set X={x1,x2,...,xn}X = \{ x_1, x_2, ..., x_n\}X={x1​,x2​,...,xn​} of nnn variables
  • Question: IS there a satisfying truth assignment for XXX with respect to CCC
  • SAT and 3-SAT are fundemental combinatorial search problems
  • We have to make nnn independent decisions (the assignments for each variable) while satisfying the set constrains
  • Satisfying each constraint in isolation is easy, but we have to make our decision so that all constraints are satisfied simultanesouly

Example

Clauses:

  • C1=x1∨0∨0C_1 = x_1 \lor 0 \lor 0C1​=x1​∨0∨0
  • C2=x2∨0∨0C_2 = x_2 \lor 0 \lor 0C2​=x2​∨0∨0
  • C3=x2ˉ∨x2ˉ∨0C_3 = \bar{x_2} \lor \bar{x_2} \lor 0C3​=x2​ˉ​∨x2​ˉ​∨0
  • Is C1∧C2C_1 \land C_2C1​∧C2​ satisfiable? Yes by x1=1,x2=1x_1 =1, x_2 = 1x1​=1,x2​=1
  • Is C1∧C3C_1 \land C_3C1​∧C3​ satisfiable? Yes by x1=1,x2=0x_1 =1, x_2 = 0x1​=1,x2​=0
  • Is C2∧C3C_2 \land C_3C2​∧C3​ satisfiable? Yes by x1=0,x2=1x_1 =0, x_2 = 1x1​=0,x2​=1
  • Is C1∧C2∧C3C_1 \land C_2 \land C_3C1​∧C2​∧C3​ satisfiable? No

3-SAT ≤P\leq_P≤P​ Independent set

  • C1=x1∨x2ˉ∨x3ˉC_1 = x_1 \lor \bar{x_2} \lor \bar{x_3}C1​=x1​∨x2​ˉ​∨x3​ˉ​
  • C2=x1ˉ∨x2∨x4C_2 = \bar{x_1} \lor x_2 \lor x_4C2​=x1​ˉ​∨x2​∨x4​
  • C3=x1ˉ∨x3∨x4ˉC_3 = \bar{x_1} \lor x_3 \lor \bar{x_4}C3​=x1​ˉ​∨x3​∨x4​ˉ​

  • Two ways to think about 3-SAT:

    • Make an independent 0/1 decision on each variable and succeed if we achieve on of three ways in which to satisfy each clause
    • Choose (at least) one term from each clause. Find a truth assignment that causes each chose term to evaluate to 1. Ensure that no two terms selected conflict e.g. select x2ˉ\bar{x_2}x2​ˉ​ in C1C_1C1​ and x2x_2x2​ in C2C_2C2​
  • We are given an instance of 3-SAT with kkk clauses of length three over nnn variables

  • Construct an instance of Independent Set: graph G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E) with 3k3k3k nodes

    • For each clause Ci,1≤i≤kC_i, 1 \leq i \leq kCi​,1≤i≤k, add a triangle of three nodes vi1,vi2,vi3v_{i1}, v_{i2}, v_{i3}vi1​,vi2​,vi3​ and three edges to GGG
    • Label each node vij,1≤j≤3v_{ij}, 1 \leq j \leq 3vij​,1≤j≤3 with the jjjth term in CiC_iCi​
    • Add an edge between each pair of nodes whose labels correspond to terms that conflict
    • N.B. size of largest IS is kkk
    • x4x_4x4​ can be assigned either 0 or 1 to satisfy the clauses.
  • Claim: 3-SAT instance is satisfiable iff GGG has an independent set of size kkk
  • Satisfiable assignment →\rightarrow→ Independent Set of size kkk: Each triangle in GGG has at least one node whose label evaluates to 1. Set SSS of nodes consisteing of one such node from each triangle forms an independent set of size = kkk. Why?
  • Independent Set of size kkk →\rightarrow→ Satisfiable assignment: the size of this set is kkk. How do we construct a ssatisfying truth assignment from the nodes in the independent set?
  • For each variable xix_ixi​, only xix_ixi​ or xiˉ\bar{x_i}xi​ˉ​ is the label of a node in SSS.
  • If xix_ixi​ is the label of a node in SSS, set xi=1x_i = 1xi​=1; else set xi=0x_i = 0xi​=0

Transitivity of Reductions

  • Claim: If Z≤PYZ \leq_P YZ≤P​Y and Y≤PXY \leq_P XY≤P​X, than Z≤PXZ \leq_P XZ≤P​X

    • Note that If Z≤PYZ \leq_P YZ≤P​Y, then Y≤PZY \leq_P ZY≤P​Z ? False
  • We have shown that 3-SAT ≤P\leq_P≤P​ Independent Set ≤P\leq_P≤P​ Vertex Covert ≤P\leq_P≤P​ Set Cover

Finding vs. Certifying

  • Is it easy to check if a given set of vertices in an undirected graph forms an independent set of size at least kkk
  • Is it east to check if a particular truth assignment satisfies a set of clauses?
  • We draw a contrast between finding a solution and checking a solution (in polynomial time)
  • Since we have not been able to develop efficient algorithms to solve many decision problems, let us turn our attention to whether we can check if a proposed solution is correct

Problems and Algorithms

Primes

  • Instance: A natural number nnn
  • Question: Is nnn prime?
  • Decision problem XXX: for every input sss answer X(s)X(s)X(s) is yes or no
  • An algorithm AAA for a decision problem receives an input sss and returns A(S)∈{yes,no}A(S) \in \{ yes, no \}A(S)∈{yes,no}

  • An algorithm AAA solves the problem XXX if for every input sss

    • if X(s)=yesX(s) = yesX(s)=yes then A(s)=yesA(s) = yesA(s)=yes and
    • if X(s)=noX(s) = noX(s)=no then A(s)=noA(s) = noA(s)=no

  • AAA has a polynomial running time if there is a polynomial function p(∙)p(\bullet)p(∙) such that for every input sss, AAA terminates on sss in at most O(p(∣s∣)O(p(|s|)O(p(∣s∣) steps

    • There is an algorithm such that p(∣s∣)=∣s∣12p(|s|) = |s|^{12}p(∣s∣)=∣s∣12 for the Primes problem, improved to ∣s∣6|s|^6∣s∣6
  • P\mathcal PP: is a set of problems XXX for which there is a polynomial time algorithm
  • A decision problem XXX is in P\mathcal PP iff there is an algorithm AAA with polynomial running time that solves XXX

Efficient Certification

  • A "checking" algorithm for a decision problem XXX has a different structure from an algorithm that solves XXX
  • Checking an algorithm needs input sss as well as a separate "certificate" ttt that contain evidence that X(s)=yesX(s) = yesX(s)=yes

  • An algorithm BBB is an efficient certifier for a problem XXX if

    • BBB is a polynomial time algorithm that takes two inputs s,ts,ts,t and

    • for all inputs sss:

      • X(s)=yesX(s) = yesX(s)=yes iff there is a certificate ttt such that B(s,t)=yesB(s,t) = yesB(s,t)=yes, and
      • the size of ttt is polynomial in the size of sss
  • Certifier's job is to take a candidate certificate ttt that s∈Xs \in Xs∈X and check in polynomial time whether ttt is a correct certififcate
  • Certificate ttt must be "short" so that certifier can run in polynomial time
  • Certifier does not care about how to find these certificates

NP\mathcal {NP}NP

  • P\mathcal PP: Set of problems XXX for which there is a polynomial time algorithm
  • NP\mathcal NPNP: Set of all problems for which there exists an efficient certifier

  • 3-SAT ∈P\in \mathcal P∈P

    • Certificate ttt: a truth assignment to the variables
    • Certifier BBB: checks whether the assignment causes every clause to evaluate to true

  • Independent set ∈P\in \mathcal P∈P

    • Certificate ttt: a set of at least kkk vertices
    • Certifier BBB: checks that no pair of vertices are connected by an edge

  • Set Cover ∈P\in \mathcal P∈P:

    • Certificate ttt: a list of kkk sets from the collection
    • Certifier BBB: checks if the union of these sets is UUU

P\mathcal {P}P vs. NP\mathcal {NP}NP

  • Claim: P⊆NP\mathcal{P} \subseteq \mathcal{NP}P⊆NP

    • Let XXX be any problem in \mathcal{P}
    • There is a polynomial time algorithm AAA that solves XXX

    • BBB ignores ttt and simply returns A(s)A(s)A(s). Why is BBB an efficient certifier

      • BBB just has to check the certificate, not compute it
  • Is P=NP\mathcal{P} = \mathcal{NP}P=NP or is NP−P≠0\mathcal{NP} - \mathcal{P} \neq 0NP−P​=0. Major unsolved problem in CS

Summary

  • P⊆NP\mathcal{P} \subseteq \mathcal{NP}P⊆NP
  • 3-SAT, Vertex Cover, Set Cover, Independent Set are in NP\mathcal{NP}NP
  • 3-SAT ≤P\leq_P≤P​ Independent Set ≤P\leq_P≤P​ Vertex Cover ≤P\leq_P≤P​ Set Cover

  • What is the structure of the problems in NP\mathcal{NP}NP

    • Is there a sequence of problems X1,X2,X3,...X_1, X_2, X_3, ...X1​,X2​,X3​,... in NP\mathcal{NP}NP, such that X1≤PX2≤X3...X_1 \leq_P X_2 \leq X_3 ...X1​≤P​X2​≤X3​...
    • Are there two problems X1X_1X1​ and X2X_2X2​ in NP\mathcal{NP}NP such that there is no problem X∈NPX \in \mathcal{NP}X∈NP such that there is no problem

NP\mathcal {NP}NP-Complete and NP\mathcal {NP}NP-Hard problems

  • A problem XXX is NP\mathcal {NP}NP-Complete if

    • X∈NPX \in \mathcal{NP}X∈NP and
    • for every problem Y∈NP,Y≤PXY \in \mathcal NP, Y \leq_P XY∈NP,Y≤P​X

  • A problem XXX is NP\mathcal {NP}NP-Hard if

    • for every problem Y∈NP,Y≤PXY \in \mathcal NP, Y \leq_P XY∈NP,Y≤P​X
  • Claim: Suppose XXX is NP\mathcal {NP}NP-Complete, then X∈PX \in \mathcal PX∈P iff P∈NP\mathcal P \in NPP∈NP
  • Corollary: If there is any problem in NP\mathcal NPNP that cannot be solved in polynomial time, then no NP\mathcal NPNP-Complete problem can be solved in polynomial time
  • Does even one NP\mathcal NPNP-Complete problem exist?! If it does, how can we prove that every problem in NP\mathcal NPNP reduces to this problem

Circuit Satisfiability

  • Cook-Levin Theorem: Circuit Satisfiability is NP\mathcal NPNP-Complete

  • A circuit KKK is a labelled, directed acyclic graph such that

    • the sources in KKK are labelled with constants (0 or 1) or the name of a distinct variable (the inputs of the circuit)
    • every other node is labeled with one Boolean operator ∧,∨,¬\land, \lor, \neg∧,∨,¬
    • a single node with not outgoing edges represents the output of KKK
  • Instance: A circuit KKK
  • Question: Is there a truth assignment to the inputs that causes the output to have value 1?

13 - NP-Complete Problems

Proving Other Problems NP\mathcal NPNP-Complete

  • Claim: If YYY is NP\mathcal NPNP-Complete and X∈NPX \in \mathcal NPX∈NP such that Y≤PY \leq_PY≤P​, then XXX is NP\mathcal NPNP-Complete

  • Recall that XXX is NP\mathcal NPNP-Complete if

    • XXX is in NP\mathcal NPNP and
    • for every problem ZZZ in NP\mathcal NPNP, Z≤PXZ \leq_P XZ≤P​X

  • Given a new problem XXX, a general strategy for proving it NP\mathcal NPNP-Complete is

    • Prove that X∈NPX \in \mathcal NPX∈NP
    • Select a problem YYY known to be NP\mathcal NPNP-Complete
    • Prove that X≤PYX \leq_P YX≤P​Y

3-SAT is NP\mathcal NPNP-Complete

  • Why is 3-SAT in NP\mathcal NPNP

  • Circuit Satifiability ≤P\leq_P≤P​ 3-SAT

    • Given an input to Circuit Satisfiability, create an input to SAT in which each clause has at most 3 variables
    • Convert this input to SAT into an input to 3-SAT

More NP\mathcal NPNP-Complete Problems

  • Circuit Satisfiability is NP\mathcal NPNP-Complete
  • We just show Circuit Satisfiability ≤P\leq_P≤P​ 3-SAT
  • 3-SAT ≤P\leq_P≤P​ IS ≤P\leq_P≤P​ VC ≤P\leq_P≤P​ Set Cover
  • All of these problems are in NP\mathcal NPNP
  • Therefore, all NP\mathcal NPNP-Complete problems are reducible to each other

Hamiltonian Cycle

  • Problems we have seen so far involve searching over subsets of a collection of objects
  • Another type of computationally hard problem involves searching over the set of all permutations of a collection of objects
  • In a directed graph G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E), a cycle CCC is a Hamiltonian Cycle if CCC visits each vertex exactly once
  • Instance: A directed graph GGG
  • Question: Does GGG contain a Hamiltonian Cycle?

Hamiltonian Cycle is NP\mathcal NPNP-Complete

  • Claim: 3-SAT ≤P\leq_P≤P​ Hamiltonian Cycle
  • Proof coming up

Travelling Salesman Problem

  • A salesman must visit nnn cities v1,v2,...,vnv_1, v_2, ..., v_nv1​,v2​,...,vn​ starting at home city v1v_1v1​
  • Salseman must find a tourtourtour, an order in which to visit each city exactly once and return home
  • Goal is to find as short a tour as possible
  • For every pair vi,vjv_i, v_jvi​,vj​ d(vi,vj)>0d(v_i, v_j) > 0d(vi​,vj​)>0 is the distance between them
  • a tour is a permutation of v1,v2,...,vnv_1, v_2, ..., v_nv1​,v2​,...,vn​
  • The length of a tour is ∑j=1n−1=d(vij,vij+1+d(vin,vi1)\sum_{j=1}^{n-1} = d(v_{i_j}, v_{i_{j+1}} + d(v_{i_n}, v_{i_1})∑j=1n−1​=d(vij​​,vij+1​​+d(vin​​,vi1​​)
  • Instance: A set VVV of nnn cities, a function d:V×V→R+d : V \times V \rightarrow \Reals^+d:V×V→R+, anda number D>0D > 0D>0
  • Question: Is there a tour of length at most DDD

14 - Coping with NP-Completeness

  • These problems come up in real life

  • NP\mathcal{NP}NP-Complete means that a problem is hard to solve in the worse case. Can we come up with better solutions at least in some cases?

    • Develop algorithms that are exponential in one parameter in the problem
    • Consider special cases of the input e.g. graphs that "look like" trees
    • Develop algorithms that can provably compute a solution close to the optimal

Vertex Cover

  • Instance: Undirected graph GGG and an integer kkk
  • Question: Does GGG contain a vertex cover of size at most kkk?
  • Problem has two parameters: k,nk,nk,n
  • What is the running time of a brute force algorithm: O(kn(nk))=O(knk+1)O(kn {n \choose k}) = O(kn^{k+1})O(kn(kn​))=O(knk+1)

  • Can we devise an algorithm whose running time is exponential in kkk but polynomial in nnn e.g. O(2kn)O(2^kn)O(2kn)

    • Fixed parameter tractable

Designing the Vertex Cover Algorithm

  • Intuition: if a graph has a small Vertex Cover, it cannot have too many edges
  • Claim: If GGG has nnn nodes and GGG has a vertex cover of size at most kkk, then GGG has at most knknkn edges
  • Easy part of algorithm: Return no if GGG has more than knknkn edges
  • G−{u}G - \{ u \}G−{u} is the graph GGG w/o the node uuu and the edge incident on uuu

  • Consier an edge (u,v)(u,v)(u,v). Either uuu or vvv must be in the vertex cover

    • Claim: GGG has a vertex cover of size at most kkk iff for any edge (u,v)(u,v)(u,v) either G−{u}G - \{ u \}G−{u} or G−{v}G - \{ v \}G−{v} has a vertex cover of size at most k−1k-1k−1

Analysing the Vertex Cover Algorithm

  • Develop a recurrence relation for the algorithm with parameters
  • Let T(n,k)T(n,k)T(n,k) denote the worst-case running time of the algorithm on an instance of Vertex Cover with parameters n,kn,kn,k
  • T(n,1)≤cnT(n, 1) \leq cnT(n,1)≤cn

  • T(n,k)≤2T(n,k−1)+cknT(n, k) \leq 2T(n, k-1) + cknT(n,k)≤2T(n,k−1)+ckn

    • We need O(kn)O(kn)O(kn) time to count the number of edges
  • Claim: T(n,k)=O(2kkn)T(n,k) = O(2^kkn)T(n,k)=O(2kkn)

Solving NP\mathcal{NP}NP-Hard Problems on Trees

  • "NP\mathcal{NP}NP-Hard: at least as hard as NP\mathcal{NP}NP-Complete. We use NP\mathcal{NP}NP-Hard to refer to optimisation version of decision problems
  • Many NP\mathcal{NP}NP-Hard problems can be solved efficiently on tree
  • Intuition: subtree rooted at any node vvv pf the tree interacts with the rest of the treee only through vvv. Therefore, depending on whether we include vvv in the solution or not, we can decouple solving the problem in vvv's subtree from the rest of the tree

Approximation Algorithms

  • Methods for optimisation version of NP\mathcal{NP}NP-Complete Problems
  • Run in polynomial time
  • Solution returned is guaranteed to be within a small factor of the optimal solution

Approximation Algorithm for Vertex Cover

Initially, C,E′←∅,∅While G has at least one edge Let (u,v) be any edge in GAdd u,v to CG←G−{u,v}Add (u,v) to E′Return C\boxed{ \begin{aligned} &\text{Initially, } C, E' \leftarrow \empty, \empty \\ &\text{While } G \text{ has at least one edge } \\ &\quad\text{Let } (u,v) \text{ be any edge in } G \\ &\quad\text{Add } u,v \text{ to } C \\ &\quad G \leftarrow G - \{u,v\} \\ &\quad\text{Add } (u,v) \text{ to } E' \\ &\text{Return } C\\ \end{aligned} } ​Initially, C,E′←∅,∅While G has at least one edge Let (u,v) be any edge in GAdd u,v to CG←G−{u,v}Add (u,v) to E′Return C​​
  • Running time is linear on the size of the graph
  • Claim: CCC is a vertex cover
  • Claim: No two edges in E′E'E′ can be covered by the same node
  • Claim: The size c∗c^*c∗ of the smallest vertex cover is at least ∣E′∣|E'|∣E′∣
  • Claim: ∣C∣=2∣E′∣≤2c∗|C| = 2|E'| \leq 2c^*∣C∣=2∣E′∣≤2c∗
  • No approximation algorithm with a factor better than 1.3606 is possible unless P=NP\mathcal{P=NP}P=NP (Dinur, Safra 2006)
  • No approximation algorithm with a factor better than 2 is possible if the "unique games conjecture" is true (Khot, Regev 2008)

Load Balancing Problem

  • Given a set of mmm machines M1,M2,...,MmM_1, M_2, ...,M_mM1​,M2​,...,Mm​
  • Given a set of nnn jobs: job jjj has processing time tjt_jtj​
  • Assign each job to one machine so that the time spent is minimised
  • Let A(i)A(i)A(i) be the set of jobs assigned to machine MiM_iMi​
  • Total time spent on machine iii is Ti=∑k∈A(i)tkT_i = \sum_{k \in A(i)} t_kTi​=∑k∈A(i)​tk​

  • Minimise makespan T=max⁡iTiT = \max_i T_iT=maxi​Ti​, the largest load on any machine

    • This is NP\mathcal{NP}NP-Complete
AlgorithmhereAlgorithm hereAlgorithmhere

Lower Bounds on the Optimal Makespan

  • Need a lower bound on the optimum makespan T∗T^*T∗
  • The two bound below suffice:
T∗≥1m∑jtj≥max⁡jtj\begin{aligned} T^* &\geq \frac{1}{m} \displaystyle \sum_j t_j \\ &\geq \max \limits_j t_j \end{aligned}T∗​≥m1​j∑​tj​≥jmax​tj​​
  • Claim: computed makespane T≤2T∗T \leq 2T^*T≤2T∗
  • Let MiM_iMi​ be the machine whose load is TTT and jjj be the last job placed on MiM_iMi​

  • What was the situation just before placing this job?

    • MiM_iMi​ had the smallest load and its load was T−tjT - t_jT−tj​
    • For every machine MkM_kMk​, load Tk≥T−tjT_k \geq T - t_jTk​≥T−tj​
∑kTk≥m(T−tj) k ranges over all machines ∑jtj≥m(T−tj) j ranges over all jobs T−tj≤1/m∑jtj≤T∗T≤2T∗, since tj≤T∗\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \sum_k T_k &\geq m(T - t_j) \text{ k ranges over all machines }\\ \displaystyle \sum_j t_j &\geq m(T - t_j) \text{ j ranges over all jobs } \\ T - t_j &\leq 1/m \displaystyle \sum_j t_j \leq T^* \\ T &\leq 2T^*, \text{ since } t_j \le T^* \end{aligned}k∑​Tk​j∑​tj​T−tj​T​≥m(T−tj​) k ranges over all machines ≥m(T−tj​) j ranges over all jobs ≤1/mj∑​tj​≤T∗≤2T∗, since tj​≤T∗​

Improving the Bound

  • It is easy to construct an example for which the greedy algorithm produces a solution close to a factor of 2 away from the optimal
  • How can we improve?
  • What if we process the jobs in decreasing order of processing time

Analyzing Sorted-Balance

  • Claim: if there are fewer than mmm jobs, algorithm is optimal

  • Claim: if there are more than mmm jobs, then T∗≥2tm+1T^* \geq 2t_{m+1}T∗≥2tm+1​

    • Consider only the first m+1m+1m+1 jobs in sorted order
    • Consider any assignment of these m+1m+1m+1 jobs to machines
    • Some machine must be assigned two hobs, each with processing time ≥tm+1\geq t_{m+1}≥tm+1​
    • This machine will have a load at least 2tm+12t_{m+1}2tm+1​
  • Claim: T≤3T∗/2T \leq 3T^*/2T≤3T∗/2
  • Let MiM_iMi​ be the machine whose load is TTT and jjj be the last job placed on MiM_iMi​ (MiM_iMi​ has at least two jobs)
tj≤T∗/2 since j≥m+1T−tj≤T∗ from Greedy-Balance proofT≤3T∗/2\begin{aligned} t_j &\leq T^*/2 \text{ since } j \geq m +1\\ T - t_j &\leq T^* \text{ from Greedy-Balance proof}\\ T &\leq 3T^*/2 \end{aligned}tj​T−tj​T​≤T∗/2 since j≥m+1≤T∗ from Greedy-Balance proof≤3T∗/2​
  • There is an even better bound T≤4T∗/3T \leq 4T^* / 3T≤4T∗/3
  • polynomial-time approximation scheme: for every ϵ>0\epsilon >0ϵ>0, compute solution with makespan T≤(1+ϵ)T∗T \leq (1 + \epsilon)T^*T≤(1+ϵ)T∗ in O((n/ϵ)1/ϵ2)O((n/\epsilon)^{1/\epsilon^2})O((n/ϵ)1/ϵ2)

Partition Problem

  • Instance: a set of nnn natural numbers w1,w2,...,wnw_1, w_2, ..., w_nw1​,w2​,...,wn​
  • Solution: a subset SSS of numbers such that ∑i∈Swi=∑i∉Swi\sum_{i \in S} w_i = \sum_{i \notin S} w_i∑i∈S​wi​=∑i∈/​S​wi​

Subset Sum Problem

  • Instance: a set of nnn natural numbers w1,w2,...,wnw_1, w_2, ..., w_nw1​,w2​,...,wn​ and a target WWW
  • Solution: a subset SSS of numbers such that ∑i∈Swi\sum_{i \in S} w_i∑i∈S​wi​ is maximized subject to the constraint ∑i∈Swi≤W\sum_{i \in S} w_i \leq W∑i∈S​wi​≤W
  • OPT(i,w)OPT(i, w)OPT(i,w) is the largest sum possible using only the first iii numbers with target www
OPT(i,w)=OPT(i−1,w),i>0,wi>wOPT(i,w)=max⁡(OPT(i−1,w),wi+OPT(i−1,w−wi)),i>0,wi≤wOPT(0,w)=0\begin{aligned} OPT(i, w) &= OPT(i-1, w), \quad i > 0, w_i > w \\ OPT(i, w) &= \max(OPT(i-1, w), w_i + OPT(i-1, w - w_i)), \quad i > 0, w_i \leq w\\ OPT(0, w) &= 0 \end{aligned}OPT(i,w)OPT(i,w)OPT(0,w)​=OPT(i−1,w),i>0,wi​>w=max(OPT(i−1,w),wi​+OPT(i−1,w−wi​)),i>0,wi​≤w=0​
  • Running itme is O(nW)O(nW)O(nW)
  • All of these are NP\mathcal{NP}NP-Complete: 3D-Matching ≤P\leq_P≤P​ Partition ≤P\leq_P≤P​ Subset Sum ≤P\leq_P≤P​ Knapsack

Knapsack Problem

  • Instance: a set of nnn elements, with each element iii having a weight wiw_iwi​ and a value viv_ivi​, and a knapsack capacity of WWW
  • Solution: a subset SSS of items such that ∑i∈Svi\sum_{i \in S} v_i∑i∈S​vi​ is maximized subject to the constraint ∑i∈Swi≤W\sum_{i \in S} w_i \leq W∑i∈S​wi​≤W

Dynamic Programming for Knapsack

  • Can generalize the DP program for Subset Sum
  • Develop a different DP program that will be useful later
  • OPT(i,v)OPT(i,v)OPT(i,v) is the smallest knapsack weight so that there is a solution using only the first iii items with total value ≥v\geq v≥v

  • What are the ranges of i,vi,vi,v?

    • iii ranges between 0,n0,n0,n, the number of items
    • Given i,vi,vi,v ranges between 0,∑1≤j≤ivj0, \sum_{1 \leq j\leq i} v_j0,∑1≤j≤i​vj​
    • Largest value of vvv is ∑1≤j≤nvn≤nv∗\sum_{1 \leq j \leq n}v_n \leq nv^*∑1≤j≤n​vn​≤nv∗ where nv∗=max⁡ivinv^* = \max_i v_inv∗=maxi​vi​
  • The solution we want is the largest value vvv such that OPT(n,v)≤WOPT(n,v) \leq WOPT(n,v)≤W
  • OPT(i,0)=0OPT(i,0) =0OPT(i,0)=0 for every i≥1i \geq 1i≥1
  • OPT(i,v)=max⁡(OPT(i−1,v),wi+OPT(i−1,v−vi))OPT(i,v) = \max (OPT(i-1, v), w_i + OPT(i-1, v-v_i))OPT(i,v)=max(OPT(i−1,v),wi​+OPT(i−1,v−vi​)), otherwise
  • Can find items in the solution by tracing back
  • Running time is O(n2v∗)O(n^2v^*)O(n2v∗) which is pseudo-polynomial in the input size

Intuition underlying Approximation Algorithm

  • What is the running time if all values are the same
  • What if they're all small integers

  • Idea:

    • round and scale all the values to lie in a smaller range
    • run the DP algorithm with the modified new values
    • Return items in this optimal solution
    • prove that the value of this solution is not much smaller than the true optimum

Approximation Scheme for Knapsack

  • 0<ϵ<10 < \epsilon < 10<ϵ<1 is a precision parameter: assume that 1/ϵ1/ \epsilon1/ϵ is an integer
  • Scaling factor θ=ϵv∗2n\theta = \frac{\epsilon v^*}{2n}θ=2nϵv∗​

  • for every item iii, and set:

    • vi~=⌈viθ⌉θ\widetilde{v_i} = \lceil \frac{v_i}{\theta} \rceil \thetavi​​=⌈θvi​​⌉θ
    • vi^=⌈viθ⌉\widehat{v_i} = \lceil \frac{v_i}{\theta} \rceilvi​​=⌈θvi​​⌉

  • algorithm:

    • solve knapsack problems using the DP program with the values vi^\widehat{v_i}vi​​
    • Return the set SSS of items found

    • Running time of Knapsack-Approx? O(n2max⁡ivi^)=O(n2v∗/θ)=O(n3/ϵ)O(n^2 \max_i \widehat{v_i}) = O(n^2v^*/\theta) = O(n^3/\epsilon)O(n2maxi​vi​​)=O(n2v∗/θ)=O(n3/ϵ)

      • Have to include ϵ\epsilonϵ here because it determines the size of the input
    • We need to show that the value of the solution returned by Knapsack-Approx is good

Approximation Guarantee for Knapsack-Approx

  • Let SSS be the solution computed by Knapsack-Approx
  • Let S∗S^*S∗ be any other solution satisfying ∑j∈S∗wj≤W\sum_{j \in S^*} w_j \leq W∑j∈S∗​wj​≤W
  • Claim: ∑i∈Svi≥∑j∈S∗vj\sum_{i \in S} v_i \geq \sum_{j \in S^*} v_j∑i∈S​vi​≥∑j∈S∗​vj​
  • Since Knapsack-Approx is optimal for the values vi~\widetilde{v_i}vi​​:

∑i∈Svi~≥∑j∈S∗vj~\sum_{i \in S} \widetilde{v_i} \geq \sum_{j \in S^*} \widetilde{v_j}∑i∈S​vi​​≥∑j∈S∗​vj​​

  • Since for each i,vi≤vi~≤vi+θi, v_i \leq \widetilde{v_i} \leq v_i + \thetai,vi​≤vi​​≤vi​+θ,
∑j∈S∗vj≤∑j∈S∗vj~≤∑i∈Svi~≤∑i∈Svi+nθ=∑i∈Svi+ϵv∗2\sum_{j \in S^*} v_j \leq \sum_{j \in S^*} \widetilde{v_j} \leq \sum_{i \in S} \widetilde{v_i } \leq \sum_{i \in S} v_i + n \theta = \sum_{i \in S} v_i + \frac{\epsilon v^*}{2}j∈S∗∑​vj​≤j∈S∗∑​vj​​≤i∈S∑​vi​​≤i∈S∑​vi​+nθ=i∈S∑​vi​+2ϵv∗​
  • Apply argument to S∗S^*S∗ containing only the items with the largest value:

mathmathmath

  • Therefore

∑j∈S∗vj≤∑i∈Svi+ϵv∗2≤(1+ϵ)∑i∈Svi\sum_{j \in S^*} v_j \leq \sum_{i \in S} v_i + \frac{\epsilon v^*}{2} \leq (1 + \epsilon) \sum_{i \in S} v_i∑j∈S∗​vj​≤∑i∈S​vi​+2ϵv∗​≤(1+ϵ)∑i∈S​vi​

  • The running time can be improved to O(nlog⁡21ϵ+1ϵ4)O(n \log_2 \frac{1}{\epsilon} + \frac{1}{\epsilon^4})O(nlog2​ϵ1​+ϵ41​)
